Block.P: First port that is not blocked

Object.P:
Trampoline Alarm block.
Maximum Counter Value = The maximum value of the counter, or maximum absolute alarm time Timer Period = Period between counter ticks AutoStart = check if Alarm is set on system startup Initial Alarm Time = Initial Alarm time, in timer Ticks Initial Cycle Time = Initial Cycle time.
Use internal Global functions to set or cancel the alarm: setAbsAlarm(increment, cycleTime) setRelAlarm(increment, cycleTime) cancelAlarm()

Trampoline Alarm block.
Maximum Counter Value = The maximum value of the counter, or maximum absolute alarm time Timer Period = Period between counter ticks AutoStart = check if Alarm is set on system startup Initial Alarm Time = Initial Alarm time, in timer Ticks Initial Cycle Time = Initial Cycle time.
Use internal Global functions to set or cancel the alarm: setAbsAlarm(increment, cycleTime) Sets the alarm using an absolute timer value. This value is compared with the current timer count. increment = the absolute timer value on which the alarm triggers cycleTime = the period of the alarm after the first trigger setRelAlarm(increment, cycleTime) Sets the alarm using a relative timer value. The alarm triggers after the relative number of timer ticks have elapsed. increment = the relative amount of ticks after which the alarm triggers cycleTime = the period of the alarm after the first trigger cancelAlarm() Cancels the alarm.
When using multiple alarms are used, the global functions should be renamed. Best method is to add a number as alarm identifier e.g. cancelAlarm1(). This is an unfortunate side-effect of SimEvents blocks not supporting function scoping.

Annotation.P: the split between setAlarm and setAbsAlarm is made such that when creating multiple alarms, only these global functions require renaming, and everything else keeps functioning.

The subsytem is set to default condition 0, and triggers on rising edge. Initial Condition block is set to 1 when "AutoStart" checkbox is enabled, which in turn triggers the subsystem, and sets the alarm absolutely, since at system start the counter is 0

Object.P:
A periodic ISR. Notes: ISR Execution Time should contain at least 2 elements, of which the last element is the transition between tasks/ISRs. Set to 0 if unsure
Parameter explanation can be found in the help (press help button).

ISR ID: the ISR ID, give each task/ISR a unique ID for proper task logging and task switching
ISR Priority: the ISR Priority, higher number = higher priority. ISRs must have a higher priority than tasks. By default ISR priorities range from 11 to 20.
Task Period: Periodicity of the task
Task Execution Time: vector containing task execution times, must contain at least 2 elements. The last element is the transition between tasks. Set to 0 if unsure
Task is preemptable: check if task is preemptable, uncheck if not.
Generate Entity At OS Start: check if the ISR should be spawned at system startup.
Requires Resource: vector that indicates if the ISR requires a resource for that segment or not.

A periodic task for which only one activation is permitted. Notes: ISR Execution Time should contain at least 2 elements, of which the last element is the transition between tasks.
Parameter explanation can be found in the help (press help button).

ISR ID: the ISR ID, give each task/ISR a unique ID for proper task logging and task switching
ISR Priority: the ISR Priority, higher number = higher priority. ISRs must have a higher priority than tasks. By default ISR priorities range from 11 to 20.
Task Period: Periodicity of the task
Task Execution Time: vector containing task execution times, must contain at least 2 elements. The last element is the transition between tasks. Set to 0 if unsure
Task is preemptable: check if task is preemptable, uncheck if not.
Requires Resource: vector that indicates if the task requires a resource for that segment or not.

A periodic task for which only one activation is permitted. Notes: Task Execution Time should contain at least 2 elements, of which the last element is the transition time between tasks. Set this last element to 0 if unsure.
Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.
Parameter explanation can be found in the help (press help button).

Task ID: the task ID, give each task a unique ID for proper task logging and task switching
Task Priority: the task Priority, higher number = higher priority
Task Period: Periodicity of the task, in seconds
Maximum Activation Count: Always 1, not allowed to change for this block. The current active task counts towards this activation count.
Task Execution Time: vector containing task execution times, must contain at least 2 elements. The last element is the transition between tasks. Set to 0 if unsure.
Generate Entity At OS Start: check if the task should be activated on OS start (simulation start).
Task is preemptable: check if task is preemptable, uncheck if not.
Requires Resource: vector that indicates if the task requires a resource for that segment or not. The vector should contain 0 for no resource, or 1 and up depending on the resource ID.
Requires Event: vector that indicates if the task must wait for an event before entering this segment. Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.

A periodic task for which multiple activation can be queued. Notes: Task Execution Time should contain at least 2 elements, of which the last element is the transition between tasks. Set this last element to 0 if unsure.
Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.
Parameter explanation can be found in the help (press help button).

Task ID: the task ID, give each task a unique ID for proper task logging and task switching
Task Priority: the task Priority, higher number = higher priority
Task Period: Periodicity of the task, in seconds
Maximum Activation Count: Queue activations up to this number. The currently activated copy of the task counts towards this limit.
Task Execution Time: vector containing task execution times, must contain at least 2 elements. The last element is the transition between tasks. Set to 0 if unsure
Task is preemptable: check if task is preemptable, uncheck if not.
Generate Entity At OS Start: check if the task should be activated on OS start (simulation start).
Requires Resource: vector that indicates if the task requires a resource for that segment or not. The vector should contain 0 for no resource, or 1 and up depending on the resource ID.
Requires Event: vector that indicates if the task must wait for an event before entering this segment. Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.

A triggered task for which only one activation is permitted. Trigger the task by sending a message with constant 1 to the "Trigger Task" input. Notes: Task Execution Time should contain at least 2 elements, of which the last element is the transition between tasks. Set this last element to 0 if unsure.
Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.
Parameter explanation can be found in the help (press help button).

Task ID: the task ID, give each task a unique ID for proper task logging and task switching
Task Priority: the task Priority, higher number = higher priority
Maximum Activation Count: Always 1, not allowed to change for this block
Task Execution Time: vector containing task execution times, must contain at least 2 elements. The last element is the transition between tasks. Set to 0 if unsure
Generate Entity At OS Start: check if the task should be activated on OS start (simulation start).
Task is preemptable: check if task is preemptable, uncheck if not.
Requires Resource: vector that indicates if the task requires a resource for that segment or not.
Requires Event: vector that indicates if the task must wait for an event before entering this segment. Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.

assert(length(segmentTimes)>1, ['SegementTimes should contain at least 2 times.',... 'The last time is the time it takes to switch tasks.',... 'If Unsure, set this time to 0']); assert(requiresEvent(1) ~= 1, 'Wait for Event not supported for first segment. Set first segment time to 0 and treat second segment as first segment.')

Annotation.P: The subsytem is set to default condition 0, and triggers on rising edge. Initial Condition block is set to 1 when "Generate Entity At System Start" is enabled, which in turn triggers the subsystem, generates a message and spawns an entity

Object.P:
A triggered task for which multiple activations can be queued. Trigger the task by sending a message with constant 1 to the "Trigger Task" input. Notes: Task Execution Time should contain at least 2 elements, of which the last element is the transition between tasks. Set this last element to 0 if unsure.
Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.
Parameter explanation can be found in the help (press help button).

Task ID: the task ID, give each task a unique ID for proper task logging and task switching
Task Priority: the task Priority, higher number = higher priority
Maximum Activation Count: Always 1, not allowed to change for this block
Task Execution Time: vector containing task execution times, must contain at least 2 elements. The last element is the transition between tasks. Set to 0 if unsure
Generate Entity At OS Start: check if the task should be activated on OS start (simulation start).
Task is preemptable: check if task is preemptable, uncheck if not.
Requires Resource: vector that indicates if the task requires a resource for that segment or not.
Requires Event: vector that indicates if the task must wait for an event before entering this segment. Waiting for an event is not supported for the first segment. If this behaviour is required, set the execution time of the first segment to 0 and set requiresEvent to 1 for the second segment.

Annotation.P: The subsytem is set to default condition 0, and triggers on rising edge. Initial Condition block is set to 1 when "Generate Entity At System Start" is enabled, which in turn triggers the subsystem, generates a message and spawns an entity

Object.P:
Processes tasks. Internally, user code can be written in the central entity server. As many resources as required and one event are supported. Support for more events can be added by providing extra code, analoguous to the existing code, in the respective functions. Terminated tasks should be routed to their respective "terminating Task" inputs on the task blocks. Preempted to Ready Queue and Done Waiting to Ready Queue outputs should be routed back into the ready queue, but are provided both, in case custom handling is needed.
Parameters: Enable Task Logging: Check when task loggin should be enabled. Do not forget to add a "DrawTaskTiming" block, and to also check "Enable Task Logging" on Ready_Queue and ISR_Queue blocks.
Enable Resource Logging: Check when resource usage should be logged.
Number of resources: provide a vector containing the available resources and their priority. e.g. [10 7] results in Resource1 with priority 10 and Resource2 with priority 7

Processes tasks. Internally, user code can be written in the central entity server. As many resources as required and one event are supported. Support for more events can be added by providing extra code, analoguous to the existing code, in the respective functions. Terminated tasks should be routed to their respective "terminating Task" inputs on the task blocks. Preempted to Ready Queue and Done Waiting to Ready Queue outputs should be routed back into the ready queue, but are provided both, in case custom handling is needed.
Parameters: Enable Task Logging: Check when task loggin should be enabled. Do not forget to add a "DrawTaskTiming" block, and to also check "Enable Task Logging" on Ready_Queue and ISR_Queue blocks.
Enable Resource Logging: Check when resource usage should be logged.
Number of resources: provide a vector containing the available resources and their priority. e.g. [10 7] results in Resource1 with priority 10 and Resource2 with priority 7

Block.Name: Processor
Block.P:
% A non preemptable task will shut the gate, this prevents preemtion. % the last segment of a task is the time required to terminate this task % and start the next task. This is normally handled by the scheduler, % thus the last segment should run uninterrupted. if(entity.preemptable == false | entity.numSegments == entity.segment) if(entity.type == 1) controlGate(0); end if(entity.type == 2) %Type 2 = ISR, ISR2 have slight transition period between them, in order of µs. %On transition we can't interrupt the ISR. setGlobalInterrupts(0); end end
%For the last bit, we assume the entity to be non preemptable as its %Actually the scheduler that runs here. if(entity.numSegments == entity.segment) entity.preemptableSwitch = 1; entity.preemptable = 0; end
%------------------------------------------ % get inputs on first segment % This is not neccesarry, but usually this is how % You'd work when running matlab code on an embedded processor. %------------------------------------------ switch entity.ID case 1 %Task with ID 1 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert inputs here end case 3 %Task with ID 3 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert inputs here end case 4 %Task with ID 4 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert inputs here end end
%Change state to running %Not really used anywhere, but can possibly be useful entity.state = 2;
% Resource management % Calls resourceCtrl, which implements a very basic version of OSEK priority ceiling (with 1 resource) % More resources can easily be added to the function if(entity.requiresResource(entity.segment)) entity.priorityNr = resourceCtrl(entity.requiresResource(entity.segment), entity.ID, entity.priorityNr, 1); if(entity.type == 1) entity.prioritySwitch = entity.priorityNr; else entity.prioritySwitch = entity.priorityNr; end end
% Switch input switch to port 1 % The controlSwitch switches between a looping task that went from seg => seg+1 % Setting it back to one allowes preemption from higher priority tasks, granted the gate is also open. controlSwitch(1);
%Loggin if(enableLogging == 1) drawTaskTiming(entity.ID, 1); end if(logResourceUsage == 1) drawResourceUsage(entity.requiresResource(entity.segment), 1); end

%------------------------------------------------------------------------------ %The actual execution code comes here, it is implemented as a switch on Task ID %The possible cases also contain a switch based on segment. %------------------------------------------------------------------------------ switch entity.ID case 1 %Task with ID 1 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert Code/function calls here end case 2 %Task with ID 2 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert Code/function calls here end case 3 %Task with ID 3 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert Code/function calls here end case 4 %Task with ID 4 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert Code/function calls here end case 5 %Task with ID 5 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert Code/function calls here end case 6 %Task with ID 6 switch entity.segment case 1 %Insert Code/function calls here end end %------------------------------------------------------------------------------ %More general checks come here %------------------------------------------------------------------------------
% Set remainingTime to zero % This assures that when more segments follow, their initial duration is used as executionTime entity.remainingTime = 0;
% release resource if(entity.requiresResource(entity.segment)) entity.priorityNr = resourceCtrl(entity.requiresResource(entity.segment), entity.ID, entity.priorityNr, 0); if(entity.type == 1) entity.prioritySwitch = entity.priorityNr; else entity.prioritySwitch = entity.priorityNr - 10; end end
% increment segment entity.segment = entity.segment + 1; if (entity.segment > entity.numSegments) entity.completed = 1; end
% if completed == 2, more segments follow (used in switch behind this entity processor if(entity.completed == 2) %First we check if we must wait for an event for the next segment if(entity.requiresEvent(entity.segment)) occured = eventCtrl(1, entity.ID, 1, entity.eventCompareTime); if(~occured) entity.wait = 1; %route ourselves into the FIFO wait queue. else %else provide path to loop for more segments entity.wait = 2; entity.eventCompareTime = getTime(); %set switch to 2, this task will loop in the server controlSwitch(2); end else %set switch to 2, this task will loop in the server controlSwitch(2); end end

%Certain tasks chain (or rather trigger) other tasks once they terminate. %This is done in the switch below. switch entity.ID case 1 %Task with ID 1 switch entity.segment-1 case 1 %Triggers here end case 2 %Task with ID 2 switch entity.segment-1 case 1 %Triggers here end case 3 %Task with ID 3 switch entity.segment-1 case 1 %Triggers here end case 4 %Task with ID 4 switch entity.segment-1 case 1 %Triggers here end case 5 %Task with ID 5 switch entity.segment-1 case 1 %Triggers here end case 6 %Task with ID 6 switch entity.segment-1 case 1 %Triggers here end end
% A non preemptable task will have shut the gate % Upon departure, reopen the gate. if(entity.type == 1) controlGate(1); end % An interrupt that finishes also has closed the globalinterruptsport, thus reenable if(entity.type == 2) setGlobalInterrupts(1); end
%Logging if(enableLogging == 1) drawTaskTiming(entity.ID, 2); end
if(logResourceUsage == 1) drawResourceUsage(entity.requiresResource(entity.segment-1), 2); end

Annotation.P: in case of "set", send message to FIFO wait queu to open the gate
